words.def: Abyssal plain - Flat or very gently sloping areas of the deep ocean basin floor.
words.name: Abyssal plain

words.def: Absolute dating - the process of determining a specific date (in years or some other unit of time) for an archaeological, geological or paleontological site or artifact.
words.name: Absolute dating

words.def: Accretion - a process by which material is added to a tectonic plate.
words.name: Accretion

words.def: Achnelith - Small, glassy volcanic bomb, sphere, dumbbell and droplet shapes resulting from very liquid magma.
words.name: Achnelith

words.def: Acid rocks - The groups ultrabasic, basic, intermediate and acid constitute a series with progressively increasing SiO2 content.
words.name: Acid rocks

words.def: Aftershock - Small earthquake that follows a main shock.
words.name: Aftershock

words.def: Agglomerate - An indurated rock built of large angular rock fragments embedded in an ashy matrix and resulting from explosive volcanic activity. Occurs typically in volcanic vents.
words.name: Agglomerate

words.def: Aggregate - A mass consisting of rock or mineral fragments.
words.name: Aggregate

words.def: Albite - The end member of the plagioclase group of minerals. Ideally consists of silicate of Sodium and Aluminium, but commonly contains small quantities of potash and lime in addition. Cf Barbierite.
words.name: Albite

words.def: Alkaline - a highly basic substance that dissolves in water.
words.name: Alkaline

words.def: Alkaline rocks - The alkaline rocks are characterized by a high content of Na2O and K2O relative to the other oxides. They occur throughout the range from ultrabasic to acid, but have their strongest expression in the acid-intermediate part of the range
words.name: Alkaline rocks

words.def: Allochthonous - Either fossils, sediments, or rocks that were formed elsewhere and later transported into the location where they are presently found. An example is an Allochthon, which is a large block of rock which has been moved from its original site of formation, usually by low angle thrust faulting.
words.name: Allochthonous

words.def: Alluvial fan - a fan-shaped deposit formed where a fast flowing stream flattens, slows, and spreads typically at the exit of a canyon onto a flatter plain.
words.name: Alluvial fan

words.def: Alluvium - soil or sediments deposited by a river or other running water.
words.name: Alluvium

words.def: Amber - name for fossil resin or tree sap that is appreciated for its colour.
words.name: Amber

words.def: Amphibole - An important group of dark-coloured, rock-forming silicate minerals, including hornblende, the commonest.
words.name: Amphibole

words.def: Amphibolite - A crystalline, coarse-grained rock, containing amphibole as an essential constituent, together with feldspar and frequently garnet. Like hornblende schist, amphibolite is formed by regional metamorphism of basic igneous rocks, but is not foliated.
words.name: Amphibolite

words.def: Amygdaloidal - Amygdules or amygdales form when the gas bubbles or vesicles in volcanic lava (or other extrusive igneous rocks) are infilled with a secondary mineral such as calcite, quartz, chlorite or one of the zeolites. Rocks containing amygdules can be described as amygdaloidal.
words.name: Amygdaloidal

words.def: Anatexis - Melting of pre-existing rock. Cf Metatexis, diatexis, syntexis
words.name: Anatexis

words.def: Andalusite - One of several crystalline forms of aluminium silicate; a characteristic product if the contact metamorphism of argillaceous rocks.
words.name: Andalusite

words.def: Andesite - fine-grained igneous rock of intermediate composition. Up to half of the rock is plagioclase feldspar with the rest being ferromagnesian minerals.
words.name: Andesite

words.def: Angular unconformity - an unconformity in which younger strata overlie an erosion surface on tilted of folded layered rock.
words.name: Angular unconformity

words.def: Anorthite - The lime rich end of the plagioclase group of minerals; Silicate of calcium and aluminium, occurring in some basic igneous rocks, typically those produced by the contact metamorphism of impure calcareous sediments. Also called Indianite.
words.name: Anorthite

words.def: Anticline - an arched fold in which the layers usually dip away from the axis.
words.name: Anticline

words.def: Aphanic - Texture of carbonate sedimentary rocks characterized by individual crystals or clastic grains < 0.01mm.
words.name: Aphanic

words.def: Aphanitic - Said of the texture of igneous rock in which the crystalline components are not distinguishable by the naked eye: Both microcrystalline and cryptocrystalline textures are included.
words.name: Aphanitic

words.def: Aplogranite - a light-colored rock of granitic texture consisting mainly of alkali feldspar and quartz, with subordinate biotite; muscovite may be present.
words.name: Aplogranite

words.def: Aquifer - a body of saturated rock or sediment through which water can move readily.
words.name: Aquifer

words.def: Aragonite sea - contains aragonite and high-magnesium calcite as the primary inorganic carbonate precipitates.
words.name: Aragonite sea

words.def: Archean Eon - the oldest eon of the Earth's history.
words.name: Archean Eon

words.def: Archipelago - a chain or cluster of islands.
words.name: Archipelago

words.def: Arenaceous - Sediments consisting essentially of sand grains, that is, of quartz and rock fragments down to 0.005mm in size. Conglomerates, sandstones, grits and siltstones fall into this category Particle size 2mm to 1/16mm
words.name: Arenaceous

words.def: Arenite - a) General term for consolidated sedimentary rock composed of sand sized fragments. b) “clean” sandstone, well sorted, <10% argillaceous matrix. Opposite to Wacke. (Etymology: Arena – Latin – sand)
words.name: Arenite

words.def: Arenitic - Pertaining to, having quality of, or resembling sandstone.
words.name: Arenitic

words.def: Arkose - An arenaceous sedimentary rock. Like sandstone in its general character, but containing feldspar to at least 10%.Formed by the disintegration of the acid igneous rocks and gneisses.
words.name: Arkose

words.def: Argillaceous - Sedimentary rocks of the clay grade, i.e. composed of minute mineral fragments and crystals less than 0.005mm in diameter, also much colloidal material. Apart from finely divided detrital matter, they consist of the so-called clay minerals, such as montmorillonite, kaolinite, gibbsite and diaspore. Siltstones, mudstones, shales, clays etc.
words.name: Argillaceous

words.def: Ash - fragments less than 2 mm (0.079 inches) in diameter of pulverized rock, minerals and volcanic glass, created during volcanic eruptions.
words.name: Ash

words.def: Asphalt - sticky, black and highly viscous liquid or semi-solid that is present in most crude petroleums and in some natural deposits.
words.name: Asphalt

words.def: Asthenosphere - a region of the Earth's outer shell beneath the lithosphere. The asthenosphere is of indeterminate thickness and behaves plastically.
words.name: Asthenosphere

words.def: Augite - A complex aluminous silicate of calcium, iron and magnesium, crystallising in the monoclinic system, and occurring in many igneous rocks, particularly those of basic composition. It is an essential component of basalt, dolerite and gabbro.
words.name: Augite

words.def: Aureole - Zone surrounding igneous intrusion in which country rock shows effects of contact metamorphism.
words.name: Aureole

words.def: Autochthonous - Fossils, sediments, or rocks that were formed or produced in the location where they are now found. This term is widely applied to a coal or peat that originated at the place where the plants comprising it grew and decayed and to rocks that have not been displaced by overthrust faulting.
words.name: Autochthonous

words.def: Banded Iron Formation - distinctive type of rock often found in primordial sedimentary rocks.
words.name: Banded Iron Formation

words.def: Basalt - fine-grained, mafic, igneous rock composed predominantly of ferromagnesian minerals and with lesser amounts of calcium-rich plagioclase feldspar.
words.name: Basalt

words.def: Basement rock - the thick foundation of ancient, and oldest metamorphic and igneous rock that forms the crust of continents, often in the form of granite.
words.name: Basement rock

words.def: Basic rocks - Igneous rock with low silica content (<54%). The groups ultrabasic, basic, intermediate and acid constitute a series with progressively increasing SiO2 content.
words.name: Basic rocks

words.def: Basin - rock formation scooped out by water erosion.
words.name: Basin

words.def: Basin and Range Province - particular type of topography that covers much of the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico that is typified by elongate north-south trending arid valleys bounded by mountain ranges which also bound adjacent valleys.
words.name: Basin and Range Province

words.def: Batholith - a large discordant pluton with an outcropping area greater than 100 square kilometers.
words.name: Batholith

words.def: Bedrock - native consolidated rock underlying the surface of a terrestrial planet, usually the Earth.
words.name: Bedrock

words.def: Bioerosion - the erosion of hard ocean substrates by living organisms through a number of mechanisms.
words.name: Bioerosion

words.def: Biostratigraphy - branch of stratigraphy which focuses on correlating and assigning relative ages of rock strata by using the fossil assemblages contained within them.
words.name: Biostratigraphy

words.def: Biostratinomy - study of the processes that take place after an organism dies but before its final burial.
words.name: Biostratinomy

words.def: Biotite - A form of black mica widely distributed in igneous rocks (particularly in granites) as lustrous black crystals, with a singularly perfect cleavage. In composition it is a complex silicate, chiefly of iron and magnesium, together with potassium and hydroxyl.
words.name: Biotite

words.def: Bioturbation - displacement and mixing of sediment particles by benthic fauna (animals) or flora (plants).
words.name: Bioturbation

words.def: Blueschist - rock that forms by the metamorphism of basalt and rocks with similar composition at high pressures and low temperatures, approximately corresponding to a depth of 15 to 30 kilometers and 200 to ~500 degrees Celsius.
words.name: Blueschist

words.def: Brackish - water that has more salinity than fresh water, but not as much as seawater.
words.name: Brackish

words.def: Breadcrust bomb - Rounded, smooth-surfaced volcanic bomb with cracked surface resembling cracked crust of bread, hence the name.
words.name: Breadcrust bomb

words.def: Breccia - A coarse grained clastic rock consisting largely of angular fragments of existing rocks.
words.name: Breccia

words.def: Boudin - geological term used for structures formed by extension, where a rigid tabular body such as a bed of sandstone, is stretched and deformed amidst less competent beds. See also Boudinage.
words.name: Boudin

words.def: Bowen's reaction series - the sequence in which minerals crystallize from a cooling basaltic magma.
words.name: Bowen's reaction series

words.def: Fold Buckling (geology) - typically, folding is thought to occur by simple buckling of a planar surface and its confining volume. The volume change is accommodated by layer parallel shortening the volume, which grows in thickness.
words.name: Fold Buckling (geology)

words.def: Buckling (mechanics) - a failure mode of a rock subjected to high compressive stresses, where the actual compressive stress at the point of failure is less than the ultimate compressive stresses that the material is capable of withstanding.
words.name: Buckling (mechanics)

words.def: Calcareous - sediment, sedimentary rock, or soil type which is formed from or contains a high proportion of calcium carbonate in the form of calcite or aragonite.
words.name: Calcareous

words.def: Calcite - The crystalline form of calcium carbonate, showing trigonal symmetry and a great variety of mineral habits. It is one of the commonest of minerals in association with both igneous and sedimentary rocks.
words.name: Calcite

words.def: Calcite sea - one in which low-magnesium calcite is the primary inorganic marine calcium carbonate precipitate.
words.name: Calcite sea

words.def: Calcrete - a) Conglomerate of surficial sand and gravel cemented by calcium carbonate precipitated from solution. b) A calcareous duricrust.
words.name: Calcrete

words.def: Caldera - volcanic feature formed by the collapse of land following a volcanic eruption.
words.name: Caldera

words.def: Cambrian - the first geological period of the Paleozoic Era, lasting from 541.0 ± 1.0 to 485.4 ± 1.9 million years ago (mya) and succeeded by the Ordovician.
words.name: Cambrian

words.def: Carbon film - type of fossil, or preservation.
words.name: Carbon film

words.def: Carbonate - a salt or ester of carbonic acid.
words.name: Carbonate

words.def: Carbonate hardgrounds - surfaces of synsedimentarily-cemented carbonate layers that have been exposed on the seafloor.
words.name: Carbonate hardgrounds

words.def: Casting - process which occurs when a liquid fills a cavity and then solidifies. If the cavity originated from decomposition of dead organisms, casting may result in formation of fossils.
words.name: Casting

words.def: Cenozoic Era - the most recent of the eras; followed the Mesozoic Era.
words.name: Cenozoic Era

words.def: Chalk - soft, white, porous sedimentary rock, a form of limestone composed of calcite coccolith plates.
words.name: Chalk

words.def: Chert - fine-grained silica-rich microcrystalline, cryptocrystalline or microfibrous sedimentary rock that may contain small fossils.
words.name: Chert

words.def: Chlorite group - A group of allied minerals which may be regarded as hydrated silicates of aluminium, iron and magnesium. They crystallise in the monoclinic system and are green in colour. They occur as alteration products of such minerals as biotite and hornblende, and also in schistose rocks.
words.name: Chlorite group

words.def: Clast - An individual constituent grain or fragment of a sediment or rock produced by mechanical weathering of a rock mass.
words.name: Clast

words.def: Clastic rocks - Mechanically redeposited remains of eroded older rocks. Rocks formed of fragments, or clasts, of pre-existing rocks.
words.name: Clastic rocks

words.def: Cleavage - in structural geology and petrology, term describing the tendency of a rock to break along preferred planes of weakness, caused by the development of a planar fabric as a result of deformation.
words.name: Cleavage

words.def: Coccolith - individual plates of calcium carbonate formed by coccolithophores (single-celled algae such as Emiliania huxleyi) which are arranged around them in a coccosphere.
words.name: Coccolith

words.def: Coccolithophore - (also called coccolithophorid) - important microfossils: single-celled algae, protists and phytoplankton belonging to the division of haptophytes. They are distinguished by special calcium carbonate plates called coccoliths.
words.name: Coccolithophore

words.def: Compactions - process by which a newly deposited sediment progressively loses its original water content due to the effects of loading, this forms part of the process of lithification.
words.name: Compactions

words.def: Compression - system of forces that tend to decrease the volume of or shorten rocks.
words.name: Compression

words.def: Conchoidal - Type of fracture that gives smoothly curved surface.
words.name: Conchoidal

words.def: Concretion - volume of sedimentary rock in which a mineral cement fills the porosity (i.e. the spaces between the sediment grains).
words.name: Concretion

words.def: Conglomerate - rock consisting of individual stones that have become cemented together.
words.name: Conglomerate

words.def: Contact metamorphism - Metamorphism due to the local heating of rocks by the intrusion of magma nearby.
words.name: Contact metamorphism

words.def: Continental crust - layer of granitic, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks which form the continents and the areas of shallow seabed close to their shores, known as continental shelves.
words.name: Continental crust

words.def: Continental margin - zone of the ocean floor that separates the thin oceanic crust from thick continental crust.
words.name: Continental margin

words.def: Continental shelf - extended perimeter of each continent and associated coastal plain, which is covered during interglacial periods such as the current epoch by relatively shallow seas (known as shelf seas) and gulfs.
words.name: Continental shelf

words.def: Convergent boundary - boundary between two plates that are moving toward each other.
words.name: Convergent boundary

words.def: Copal - type of resin produced by plant or tree secretions, particularly identified with the forms of aromatic tree resins used by the cultures of pre-Columbian Mesoamerica as a ceremonially burned incense, as well as for a number of other purposes.
words.name: Copal

words.def: Coprolites - fossil that results when human or animal dung is fossilized.
words.name: Coprolites

words.def: Cordierite - A silicate of aluminium, iron and magnesium with water, which crystallises in the orthorhombic system, occurs mainly in metamorphic rocks.
words.name: Cordierite

words.def: Core - innermost layer(s) of a planet.
words.name: Core

words.def: Corestone - An ellipsoidal or broadly rectangular joint block of granite formed by subsurface weathering in the same manner as a tor but entirely separated from bedrock.
words.name: Corestone

words.def: Craton - old and stable part of the continental crust that has survived the merging and splitting of continents and supercontinents for at least 500 million years.
words.name: Craton

words.def: Cross-bedding - inclined sedimentary structures in a horizontal unit of rock; such tilted structures indicate the type of depositional environment, not post-depositional deformation.
words.name: Cross-bedding

words.def: Crude oil - a liquid mixture of naturally occurring hydrocarbons.
words.name: Crude oil

words.def: Crust - outermost solid shell of Earth planet, or of any other planet or moon.
words.name: Crust

words.def: Cryptocrystalline -
words.name: Cryptocrystalline

words.def: Dacite - an igneous, volcanic rock with a high iron content. Extrusive rock of same general composition as andesite, but a less calcic feldspar. Syn. Quartz andesite.
words.name: Dacite

words.def: Daughter product - the isotope produced by radioactive decay.
words.name: Daughter product

words.def: Delta - landform where the mouth of a river flows into an ocean, sea, desert, estuary, lake or another river.
words.name: Delta

words.def: Degradation - the lowering of a fluvial surface, such as a stream bed or floodplain, through erosional processes.
words.name: Degradation

words.def: Dendrites - crystal that develops with a typical multi-branching tree-like form.
words.name: Dendrites

words.def: Deposition - geological process by which material is added to a landform or land mass.
words.name: Deposition

words.def: Detachment fault - major fault in a mountain belt above which rocks have been intensely folded or faulted.
words.name: Detachment fault

words.def: Diagenesis - chemical, physical, or biological change undergone by a sediment after its initial deposition and during and after its lithification, exclusive of surface alteration (weathering) and metamorphism.
words.name: Diagenesis

words.def: Diamictite - a comprehensive non-generic term for a non-sorted or poorly sorted non-calcareous terrigenous sedimentary rock that contains a wide range of particle sizes such as rock with sand or larger particles in a muddy matrix.
words.name: Diamictite

words.def: Diapir - a type of intrusion in which a more mobile and ductily-deformable material is forced into brittle overlying rocks. A dome or anticlinal fold of the overlaying rocks which has been ruptured by the squeezing out of the plastic core material.
words.name: Diapir

words.def: Diatomite - naturally occurring, soft, chalk-like sedimentary rock that is easily crumbled into a fine white to off-white powder.
words.name: Diatomite

words.def: Diopside - a monoclinic pyroxene, ideally consisting of silicate of calcium and magnesium, but commonly containing a variable content of FeSi2O6 in addition, and then strictly known as ferriferous diopside
words.name: Diopside

words.def: Diorite - grey to dark grey intermediate intrusive igneous rock composed principally of plagioclase feldspar (typically andesine), biotite, hornblende, and/or pyroxene.
words.name: Diorite

words.def: Dike - or dyke - a type of sheet intrusion referring to any geologic body that cuts discordantly across.
words.name: Dike

words.def: Dip slope - geological formation often created by erosion of tilted strata.
words.name: Dip slope

words.def: Disconformity - a surface that represents missing rock strata but beds above and below that surface are parallel to one another.
words.name: Disconformity

words.def: Divergent plate boundary - boundary separating two plates moving away from each other.
words.name: Divergent plate boundary

words.def: Dolomite - name of a sedimentary carbonate rock and a mineral, both composed of calcium magnesium carbonate CaMg(CO3)2 found in crystals.
words.name: Dolomite

words.def: Dolerite - basic igneous rock of medium grain size, occurring as minor intrusions or in the central parts of thick lava flows. a) A dark-colored, basic, igneous rock, composed essentially of pyroxene and a triclinic feldspar with magnetic iron. Considered by some authors to be equivalent to a coarse-grained basalt. b) A dark, crystalline, igneous rock, chiefly pyroxene with labradorite. c) Coarse-grained basalt. d) Diabase. e) Any dark, igneous rock composed chiefly of silicates of iron and magnesium with some feldspar.
words.name: Dolerite

words.def: Drill core - drill specifically designed to remove a cylinder of material, much like a hole saw.
words.name: Drill core

words.def: Drumlin - an elongated whale-shaped hill formed by glacial action.
words.name: Drumlin

words.def: Dunite - Ultrabasic plutonic rock in which mafic material is almost entirely olivine with accessory Chromite almost always present. Feldspar mainly plagioclase. See Peridotite
words.name: Dunite

words.def: Duricrust - General term for hard crust on surface of or layer in upper horizons of a soil in semi-arid climate formed by accumulation of solid minerals deposited by water moving upwards by capillary action and evaporating in the dry season. Cf Hardpan
words.name: Duricrust

words.def: Dyke - or dike - a type of sheet intrusion referring to any geologic body that cuts discordantly across. A form of minor intrusion injected into the crust during its subjection to tension, the dyke being thin with parallel sides, and maintaining a constant direction in some cases for long distances. Some are more resistant to weathering than the surrounding rock and stand up like walls, while others weather faster and form long narrow depressions.
words.name: Dyke

words.def: Eclogite - Generally coarse to medium grained, green (reddish when weathered) pyroxene in which are set red garnets. Pistachio green when fresh, but mottled with red when weathered.
words.name: Eclogite

words.def: Eemian transgression - Late Pleistocene 120 Ka. up to 8m above present
words.name: Eemian transgression

words.def: Eon - the largest unit of geologic time.
words.name: Eon

words.def: Epicenter - point on the Earth's surface that is directly above the hypocenter or focus, the point where an earthquake or other underground explosion originates.
words.name: Epicenter

words.def: Epidiorite - altered gabbroic and doleritic rocks in which the original pyroxene has been replaced by fibrous amphibole. The rock may be regarded as a first step in the conversion by dynamothermal metamorphism of a basic igneous rock into a green schist.
words.name: Epidiorite

words.def: Epirogenetic - simultaneous rising and falling movements of continents, maintaining isostasy
words.name: Epirogenetic

words.def: Epoch - each period of the standard geologic time scale is divided into epochs (e.g., Pleistocene Epoch of the Quaternary Period).
words.name: Epoch

words.def: Erosion - displacement of solids (sediment, soil, rock and other particles) usually by the agents of currents such as, wind, water, or ice by downward or down-slope movement in response to gravity or by living organisms (in the case of bioerosion).
words.name: Erosion

words.def: Erratic - piece of rock that deviates from the size and type of rock native to the area in which it rests; stones ranging in size from pebbles to large boulders which were transported by ice, which on melting left them stranded far from their original source; the name "erratic" is based on the errant location of these boulders.
words.name: Erratic

words.def: Escarpment - transition zone between different physiogeographic provinces that involves an elevation differential, characterized by a cliff or steep slope.
words.name: Escarpment

words.def: Esker - long, winding ridge of stratified sand and gravel, examples of which occur in glaciated and formerly glaciated regions of Europe and North America. Eskers are frequently several miles in length and, because of their peculiar uniform shape, somewhat resemble railroad embankments.
words.name: Esker

words.def: Estuary - semi-enclosed coastal body of water with one or more rivers or streams flowing into it, and with a free connection to the open sea.
words.name: Estuary

words.def: Eugeosyncline - A geosyncline in which volcanism is associated with clastic sedimentation: The volcanic part of an orthosyncline located away from the craton.
words.name: Eugeosyncline

words.def: Euhedral - rock minerals which are bounded by the crystal faces peculiar to the species; ideomorphic.
words.name: Euhedral

words.def: Eustatic movements - Changes of sea level, constant over wide areas, due to alterations in the volume of the oceans resulting from formation or melting of ice caps.
words.name: Eustatic movements

words.def: Evaporite - water-soluble, mineral sediments that result from the evaporation of bodies of surface water.
words.name: Evaporite

words.def: Exfoliation - the stripping of concentric rock slabs from the outer surface of a rock mass.
words.name: Exfoliation

words.def: Extension - strain involving an increase in length. Extension can cause thinning and faulting.
words.name: Extension

words.def: Extrusive - mode of igneous volcanic rock formation in which hot magma from inside the Earth flows out (extrudes) onto the surface as lava or explodes violently into the atmosphere to fall back as pyroclastics or tuff.
words.name: Extrusive

words.def: Facies - The sum of the lithological and faunal characters of a sediment is its facies. Lithological facies involves composition, grain size, texture, colour, as well as such mass characteristics as current bedding, nature of stratification, ripple marks etc. Similarly metamorphic facies involves the degree of crystallisation and the mineral assemblage in a group of metamorphic rocks.
words.name: Facies

words.def: Fanning - rock deformation related to shear stress
words.name: Fanning

words.def: Fault - discrete planar rock fracture, which shows evidence of a displacement (the throw of the fault). A fault is a discrete surface.
words.name: Fault

words.def: Fault zone - zone where exist different discrete fault planes.
words.name: Fault zone

words.def: Feldspars - group of most common minerals of the Earth's crust. All feldspars contain silicon, aluminum, and oxygen and may contain potassium, calcium and sodium.
words.name: Feldspars

words.def: Fels - Massive metamorphic rock lacking schistosity or foliation.
words.name: Fels

words.def: Felsic - silicate minerals, magmas, and rocks which are enriched in the lighter elements such as silicon, oxygen, aluminium, sodium, and potassium. Light minerals (Quartz & Feldspar) >60% - Acid. [Granite (Rhyolite), Adamellite (Rhyo-dacite), Granodiorite (Dacite)]. Mnemonic adjective for igneous rock having light coloured minerals in its mode. From Feldspar and Silica. Opposite to Mafic.
words.name: Felsic

words.def: Ferricrete - conglomerate consisting of surficial sand and gravel cemented into a hard mass by iron oxide derived from oxidation of percolating solution of iron salts. A ferruginous duricrust.
words.name: Ferricrete

words.def: Ferromagnesian mineral - iron/magnesium bearing mineral, such as augite, hornblende, olivine or biotite.
words.name: Ferromagnesian mineral

words.def: Fission track dating - a method that uses tracks that are visible under the microscope to date minerals.
words.name: Fission track dating

words.def: Flandrian transgression -
words.name: Flandrian transgression

words.def: Fold - stack of originally flat and planar surfaces, such as sedimentary strata, are bent or curved as a result of plastic (i.e. permanent) deformation.
words.name: Fold

words.def: Foliation - parallel alignment of textural and structural features of a rock.
words.name: Foliation

words.def: Fossil - mineralized or otherwise preserved remains or traces (such as footprints) of animals, plants, and other organisms.
words.name: Fossil

words.def: Fracture - general non geological term used to indicate a crack or a discontinuity. Can only be used when no displacement can be distinguished. Vague term to avoid.
words.name: Fracture

words.def: Freezing - process whereby a liquid turns to a solid when cold enough.
words.name: Freezing

words.def: Gabbro - dark, coarse-grained, intrusive igneous rock chemically equivalent to basalt.
words.name: Gabbro

words.def: Gastroliths - rocks, which are or have been held inside the digestive tract of an animal.
words.name: Gastroliths

words.def: Geologic maps - special-purpose map made to show geological features.
words.name: Geologic maps

words.def: Geosyncline - A mobile down-warping of the crust of the earth, either elongate or basin-like, measured in scores of kilometres, which is subsiding as sedimentary and volcanic rocks accumulate to thicknesses of thousands of metres.
words.name: Geosyncline

words.def: Glass - hard, brittle, transparent solid, such as used for windows, many bottles, or eyewear, including soda-lime glass, acrylic glass, sugar glass, isinglass (Muscovy-glass), or aluminium oxynitride.
words.name: Glass

words.def: Glauconite - Hydrated silicate of potassium and iron, a green mineral that forms on submerged banks. Its occurrence in sands and sandstones is considered an indication of accumulation under marine conditions.
words.name: Glauconite

words.def: Gneiss - Coarse-grained, pale-coloured gneissose rock, containing abundant feldspar with quartz, mica, hornblende and garnet.
words.name: Gneiss

words.def: Gondwanaland - the southern part of Pangaea that formed South America, Africa, India, Australia and Antarctica.
words.name: Gondwanaland

words.def: Granite - A coarse grained, often porphyritic, intrusive, felsic, igneous rock containing megascopic quartz, averaging 25%, much feldspar (orthoclase, microcline, sodic plagioclase) and mica or other coloured minerals. Rhyolite is the volcanic equivalent
words.name: Granite

words.def: Granitoid - general term for a granite-like rock, including granite, granodiorite, diorite, monzonite, etc.
words.name: Granitoid

words.def: Granoblastic - An arrangement of mineral grains in a rock of metamorphic origin similar to that of a normal granite, but produced by recrystallisation in the solid and not by crystallisation from a molten condition.
words.name: Granoblastic

words.def: Granodiorite - intrusive felsic igneous rock similar to granite, but contains more plagioclase than potassium feldspar. Volcanic equivalent Dacite
words.name: Granodiorite

words.def: Graywacke - variety of sandstone generally characterized by its hardness, dark color, and poorly-sorted, angular grains of quartz, feldspar, and small rock fragments (lithic fragments) set in a compact, clay-fine matrix. From German Grauwacke.
words.name: Graywacke

words.def: Greenstone - An omnibus term lacking precision and applied indiscriminately to basic and intermediate igneous rocks of Lower Palaeozoic age in which much chlorite has been produced at the expense of the original coloured minerals, staining the rocks green.
words.name: Greenstone

words.def: Grus - freshly-eroded and angular grains of quartz and feldspar derived from a granitoid.
words.name: Grus

words.def: Half-life - the time it takes for a given amount of a radioactive isotope to be reduced by one-half.
words.name: Half-life

words.def: Hardpan -
words.name: Hardpan

words.def: Hemicrystalline - rocks of igneous origin which contain some interstitial glass, in addition to crystalline minerals.
words.name: Hemicrystalline

words.def: Hinge - zone of maximum curvature of a fold.
words.name: Hinge

words.def: Hinge line - a line joining the points of maximum curvature along the hinge of a fold.
words.name: Hinge line

words.def: Holocrystalline - those igneous rocks in which all the components are crystalline; glass is absent.
words.name: Holocrystalline

words.def: Hornblende - an important rock-forming mineral of complex composition, essentially silicate of calcium, magnesium and iron, with smaller amounts of potash, soda and hydroxyl; crystallises in the monoclinic system; occurs as black crystals or grains in many different types of igneous and metamorphic rocks, including hornblende-granite, syenite, diorite, andesite, etc., and hornblende-schist and amphibole.
words.name: Hornblende

words.def: Hornfels - hard, compact, fine textured contact altered argillaceous [from clay] rocks that break into splintery fragments
words.name: Hornfels

words.def: Hot springs - spring that is produced by the emergence of geothermally-heated groundwater from the Earth's crust.
words.name: Hot springs

words.def: Hydrothermal - Pertaining to heated water. The action of or products of heated water.
words.name: Hydrothermal

words.def: Hydrothermal vent - fissure in a planet's surface from which geothermally heated water issues.
words.name: Hydrothermal vent

words.def: Hypersaline - saltiness or dissolved salt content of a body of water greater than that of seawater.
words.name: Hypersaline

words.def: Ichnology - branch of biology that deals with traces of organismal behavior.
words.name: Ichnology

words.def: Idiomorphic (crystals) - Rock minerals which are bounded by the crystal faces peculiar to the species
words.name: Idiomorphic (crystals)

words.def: Igneous rock - rocks formed by solidification of cooled magma (molten rock), with or without crystallization, either below the surface as intrusive (plutonic) rocks or on the surface as extrusive (volcanic) rocks.
words.name: Igneous rock

words.def: Ignimbrite - Fine-grained to aphanitic, buff to dark brown compact rock with parallel streaks or lenticles of black glass, produced by violently explosive volcanoes.
words.name: Ignimbrite

words.def: Ilmenite - An oxide of iron and titanium, crystallising in the trigonal system; a widespread accessory mineral in igneous rocks, especially those of basic composition.
words.name: Ilmenite

words.def: Indurated - Made hard
words.name: Indurated

words.def: Interbedded - beds (layers) of rock lying between or alternating with beds of a different kind of rock.
words.name: Interbedded

words.def: Intrusion - body of igneous rock that has crystallized from molten magma below the surface of the Earth.
words.name: Intrusion

words.def: Island arc - chain of volcanic islands or mountains formed by plate tectonics as an oceanic tectonic plate subducts under another tectonic plate and produces magma.
words.name: Island arc

words.def: Isotope - different forms of an element each having different atomic mass (mass number).
words.name: Isotope

words.def: Joint - discrete discontinuity surface without evidence of displacement. See also diaclase or bedding.
words.name: Joint

words.def: Jurassic - major unit of the geologic timescale that extends from about 199.6 ± 0.6 Ma (million years ago) to 145.4 ± 4.0 Ma, the end of the Triassic to the beginning of the Cretaceous.
words.name: Jurassic

words.def: Ka - 1000 years
words.name: Ka

words.def: Kame - geological feature, an irregularly shaped hill or mound composed of sand, gravel and till that accumulates in a depression on a retreating glacier, and is then deposited on the land surface with further melting of the glacier.
words.name: Kame

words.def: Kaolinite - a finely crystalline form of hydrated aluminium silicate occurring as minute monoclinic flaky crystals with a perfect basal cleavage, resulting mainly from the alteration of feldspars under conditions of hydrothermal or pneumatolytic metamorphism.
words.name: Kaolinite

words.def: Karst - landscape shaped by the dissolution of a layer or layers of soluble bedrock, usually carbonate rock such as limestone or dolomite. Characterised by closed depressions or sinkholes, caves and underground drainage.
words.name: Karst

words.def: Kettle - fluvioglacial landform occurring as the result of blocks of ice calving from the front of a receding glacier and becoming partially to wholly buried by glacial outwash.
words.name: Kettle

words.def: Kink - tight curl, twist, or bend in a rock band. See also folding and buckling.
words.name: Kink

words.def: Kink band - an asymmetric, linear zone of deformation characterised by a tight curled, twisted, or bended rock band. Kink bands may also occur as conjugated sets.
words.name: Kink band

words.def: Kyanite - A silicate of aluminium which crystallises in the triclinic system. It usually occurs as long-bladed crystals, blue in colour, in metamorphic rocks.
words.name: Kyanite

words.def: Lacuna - A time-stratigraphic unit representing the gap in the stratigraphic record. Specifically the missing interval at an unconformity, representing the interpreted space-time value of both hiatus (period of non-deposition), and degradation vacuity (period of erosion)
words.name: Lacuna

words.def: Lamprophyres - Igneous rocks usually occurring as dykes intimately related to larger intrusive bodies; characterised by abnormally high contents of coloured silicates, such as biotite, hornblende and augite, and a correspondingly small amount of feldspar, some being feldspar-free
words.name: Lamprophyres

words.def: Lava - molten rock expelled by a volcano during an eruption.
words.name: Lava

words.def: Leucocratic - A term used to denote a light colour in igneous rocks, due to a high content of felsic minerals, and a correspondingly small amount of dark, heavy silicates.
words.name: Leucocratic

words.def: Limestone - sedimentary rock composed largely of the mineral calcite (calcium carbonate: CaCO3).
words.name: Limestone

words.def: Liquefaction - Soil liquefaction describes the behavior of soils that, when loaded, suddenly suffer a transition from a solid state to a liquefied state, or having the consistency of a heavy liquid.
words.name: Liquefaction

words.def: Lithic/Lithic fragment - A sand-sized grain that is made up of smaller than sand-sized grains, e.g. a shale fragment or basalt fragment in a sandstone.
words.name: Lithic/Lithic fragment

words.def: Lithification - the process in which sediments compact under pressure, expel connate fluids, and gradually become solid rock.
words.name: Lithification

words.def: Lithology - a description of the physical characteristics of a rock unit visible at outcrop, in hand or core samples or with low magnification microscopy, such as colour, texture, grain size, or composition.
words.name: Lithology

words.def: Loess - fine, silty, pale yellow or buff in color, windblown (eolian) type of unconsolidated deposit.
words.name: Loess

words.def: Lowland - broad expanse of land with a general low level.
words.name: Lowland

words.def: Ma - 1,000,000 years
words.name: Ma

words.def: Mafic - a silicate mineral or rock that is rich in magnesium and iron. A mnemonic term for the ferromagnesian and other non-felsic minerals actually present in an igneous rock rich in dark (ferromagnesian) minerals (>60% by volume). Basic [alkali gabbro (alkali basalt), syeno-gabbro (trachybasalt), gabbro (basalt and dolerite)]
words.name: Mafic

words.def: Magma - molten rock that sometimes forms beneath the surface of the earth (or any other terrestrial planet) that often collects in a magma chamber.
words.name: Magma

words.def: Magnetite - An oxide of iron which crystallises in the cubic system It is attracted by a magnet but does not attract iron itself.
words.name: Magnetite

words.def: Malmesbury group - 830 to 980 Ma basal group of the Western Cape comprising at least eight formations including Tygerberg, Piketberg, Porterville, Berg river, Klipplaat, Moorreesburg, Franschhoek and Bridgetown formations.
words.name: Malmesbury group

words.def: Mantle - highly viscous layer directly under the crust, and above the outer core.
words.name: Mantle

words.def: Marble - Fine to coarse-grained granoblastic calcium carbonate that effervesces in dilute hydrochloric acid. Often banded with various colours and sometimes veined.
words.name: Marble

words.def: Marine terrace - narrow flat area often seen at the base of a sea cliff caused by the action of the waves.
words.name: Marine terrace

words.def: Marl - calcium carbonate or lime-rich mud or mudstone which contains variable amounts of clays and aragonite.
words.name: Marl

words.def: Mélange - large scale breccia formed in the accretionary wedge above a subduction zone.
words.name: Mélange

words.def: Melanocratic - A term applied to rocks which are abnormally rich in dark and heavy ferro-magnesium minerals
words.name: Melanocratic

words.def: Mesocratic - A term applied to igneous rocks which in respect of their content of dark silicates are intermediate between those of leucocratic and melanocratic type, and contain 30 to 60% of dark heavy minerals.
words.name: Mesocratic

words.def: Mesozoic - The era of geological time including Triassic, Jurassic and Cretaceous ages
words.name: Mesozoic

words.def: Metamorphism - the solid state recrystallisation of pre-existing rocks due to changes in heat and/or pressure and/or introduction of fluids i.e. without melting.
words.name: Metamorphism

words.def: Metapelite - A metamorphosed pelite rock
words.name: Metapelite

words.def: Metasilicate - A salt of metasilicic acid H2SiO3.
words.name: Metasilicate

words.def: Metatexis - Low grade anatexis: partial or differential melting of rock components with low melting point.
words.name: Metatexis

words.def: Mica - A group of minerals which crystallise in the monoclinic system: They have similar chemical compositions and highly perfect basal cleavage.
words.name: Mica

words.def: Micropaleontology - branch of paleontology which studies microfossils.
words.name: Micropaleontology

words.def: Mid-oceanic ridges - underwater mountain range, typically having a valley known as a rift running along its axis, formed by plate tectonics.
words.name: Mid-oceanic ridges

words.def: Migmatite - A composite rock composed of igneous or igneous looking and/or metamorphic materials which are generally distinguishable megascopically.
words.name: Migmatite

words.def: Mineralization - hydrothermal deposition of economically important metals in the formation of ore bodies or "lodes".
words.name: Mineralization

words.def: Miogeosyncline - A geosyncline in which volcanism is not associated with sedimentation. The non-volcanic part of the orthogeosyncline located near the craton.
words.name: Miogeosyncline

words.def: Molasse - A partly marine, partly continental or deltaic sedimentary facies consisting of a very thick sequence of soft ungraded cross-bedded fossiliferous conglomerates, sandstones, shales and marls.
words.name: Molasse

words.def: Molding - process of manufacturing by shaping pliable raw material using a rigid frame or model called a mold.
words.name: Molding

words.def: Monocline - A fold with a single limb which produces a sudden steepening of the dip; the rocks however soon approximate to horizontal on either side of this flexure.
words.name: Monocline

words.def: Monoclinic (crystal) - Three crystal axes are of unequal lengths and one intersection oblique (other two perpendicular)
words.name: Monoclinic

words.def: Moraine - glacially formed accumulation of unconsolidated debris which can occur in currently glaciated and formerly glaciated regions, such as those areas acted upon by a past ice age.
words.name: Moraine

words.def: Mullion (geology) - a particular type of reworked boudin (term likely derived from an architectural structure with the same name).
words.name: Mullion (geology)

words.def: Muscovite - The common or white mica; for the most part an orthosilicate of aluminium and potassium, crystallising in the monoclinic system.
words.name: Muscovite

words.def: Namibian age - 900 to 542 Ma (Neoproterozoic)
words.name: Namibian age

words.def: Neogene - a geologic period starting 23 million years ago and lasting either until today or ending 2.6 million years ago with the beginning of the Quaternary.
words.name: Neogene

words.def: Non-clastic - Chemically/organically deposited rocks. Limestones, chalks, evaporite deposits – gypsum.
words.name: Non-clastic

words.def: Normal fault - Dip-slip faults can be sub-classified into the types "reverse" and "normal". A normal fault occurs when the crust is extended. Alternatively such a fault can be called an extensional fault. The hanging wall moves downward, relative to the footwall.
words.name: Normal fault

words.def: Oligoclase - One of the plagioclase feldspars consisting of the albite and anorthite molecules combined in the proportions 9:1 to 7:3. It is found especially in the more acid igneous rocks.
words.name: Oligoclase

words.def: Olivine - Orthosilicate of iron and magnesium, crystallising in the orthorhombic system which occur widely in the basic and ultramafic igneous rocks, and includes olivine-gabbro, olivine –dolerite, olivine-basalt, peridotites etc.
words.name: Olivine

words.def: Ordovician - The Ordovician is a geologic period and system, the second of six of the Paleozoic Era, and covers the time between 485.4 ± 1.9 to 443.4 ± 1.5 million years ago. It follows the Cambrian Period and is followed by the Silurian Period.
words.name: Ordovician

words.def: Orogenesis - the formation and growth of mountains related to tectonic activity.
words.name: Orogenesis

words.def: Orogeny - refers to forces and events leading to a large structural deformation of the Earth's lithosphere (crust and uppermost mantle) due to the engagement of tectonic plates and is the primary mechanism by which mountains are built on continents.
words.name: Orogeny

words.def: Orthoclase Silicate of potassium and aluminium. Monoclinic crystal form. Occurs as essential constituent in granitic and syenitic rocks and as accessory in many other rock types.
words.name: Orthoclase

words.def: Orthogeosyncline - A geosyncline between continental and oceanic cratons containing both volcanic and non-volcanic belts.
words.name: Orthogeosyncline

words.def: Orthorhombic - Crystal structure with three perpendicular axes all of different lengths.
words.name: Orthorhombic

words.def: Orthosilicate - Obsolete classification based on salt of hypothetical orthosilicic acid. Cf Metasilicate
words.name: Orthosilicate

words.def: Oxbow lake - a crescent-shaped lake found within a floodplain or fluvial terrace created by the cut-off and abandoned of an active meander loop by the meandering of a river.
words.name: Oxbow lake

words.def: Pahoehoe lava - Vesicular, basaltic lava often with ropy surface texture.
words.name: Pahoehoe lava

words.def: Paleocurrent - An indication of the direction of fluid flow (at the time of deposition) found in a rock.
words.name: Paleocurrent

words.def: Palaeozoic - the earliest of three geologic eras of the Phanerozoic Eon, spanning from roughly 541 to 252.2 million years ago. It is the longest of the Phanerozoic eras, and is subdivided into six geologic periods (from oldest to least old): the Cambrian, Ordovician, Silurian, Devonian, Carboniferous, and Permian. The Paleozoic comes after the Neoproterozoic Era of the Proterozoic Eon, and is followed by the Mesozoic Era.
words.name: Palaeozoic

words.def: Palagonite - an alteration product from the interaction of water with volcanic glass of chemical composition similar to basalt or from the interaction between water and basalt melt.
words.name: Palagonite

words.def: Paralithic - a weathered layer of bedrock.
words.name: Paralithic

words.def: Pegmatite - Exceptionally coarse grained igneous rock.
words.name: Pegmatite

words.def: Pelite - (Greek Pelos, Clay) - a descriptive name for a clastic rock with a grain size of less than 1/16 mm (originally sand or silt).
words.name: Pelite

words.def: Peridotite - Olive green when fresh, medium brown when weathered, saccharoidal intrusive igneous rock of mainly olivine, sometimes with pyroxene.
words.name: Peridotite

words.def: Petrology - the branch of geology that studies the origin, composition, distribution and structure of rocks.
words.name: Petrology

words.def: Phenoclast - large conspicuous fragment in sediment or sedimentary rock composed of various sizes of material.
words.name: Phenoclast

words.def: Phenocryst - a relatively large crystal in an igneous rock.
words.name: Phenocryst

words.def: Phyllite - Argillaceous rocks in a condition of metamorphism between slate and mica-schist
words.name: Phyllite

words.def: Piercing point - a feature that is cut by a fault and moved, and reconstruction of that object can show how much a fault has moved.
words.name: Piercing point

words.def: Pitchstone - Black, opaque volcanic glass that may contain irregular, whitish clusters of minerals. Resembles pitch in appearance.
words.name: Pitchstone

words.def: Plate tectonics (from the Greek τέκτων; tektōn, meaning "builder" or "mason") describes the large scale motions of Earth's lithosphere.
words.name: Plate tectonics

words.def: Pleistocene - the geological epoch which lasted from about 2,588,000 to 11,700 years ago, spanning the world's recent period of repeated glaciations. The Pleistocene is the first epoch of the Quaternary Period or sixth epoch of the Cenozoic Era
words.name: Pleistocene

words.def: Pliocene - the period in the geologic timescale that extends from 5.332 million to 2.588[2] million years before present. It is the second and youngest epoch of the Neogene Period in the Cenozoic Era. The Pliocene follows the Miocene Epoch and is followed by the Pleistocene Epoch.
words.name: Pliocene

words.def: Plutonic - Rocks that crystallised at depth within the crust. Slow cooling, coarse grain size and relatively low temperature of final consolidation.
words.name: Plutonic

words.def: Plumose structure - ladder or grid patterns that occur during jointing that resemble plumes, oriented perpendicular to the stress, hence which usually form parallel to the upper and lower surfaces of the constituent rock unit.
words.name: Plumose structure

words.def: Pneumatolysis - The destructive after action of the concentrated volatile constituents of a magma, effected after the consolidation of the main body of the magma.
words.name: Pneumatolysis

words.def: Polymictic -
words.name: Polymictic

words.def: Polysynthetic twinning -
words.name: Polysynthetic twinning

words.def: Porphyroblast - a large mineral crystal in a metamorphic rock which has grown within the finer grained groundmass.
words.name: Porphyroblast

words.def: Porphyry - Rock that is porphyritic, containing large and small crystals, or, in mining, a specific deposit containing widely disseminated metals, typically copper.
words.name: Porphyry

words.def: Precambrian - Earth's history before the Phanerozoic Eon, divided into several eons of the geologic time scale. It spans from the formation of Earth about 4540 Ma (million years ago) to the beginning of the Cambrian Period, about 541.0 ± 1.0 Ma, when macroscopic hard-shelled animals first appeared in abundance.
words.name: Precambrian

words.def: Prograde metamorphism - mineral changes in rocks under increasing pressure and/or temperature conditions
words.name: Prograde metamorphism

words.def: Protolith - the source rock from which a metamorphic, or in some rare cases a sedimentary, rock was formed. In most cases the appropriate sedimentary term is "provenance" rather than "protolith", since the material has been transported.
words.name: Protolith

words.def: Psammite - (Greek Psammos, Sand) - a general term for a sandstone, most often used to describe a metamorphosed rock unit with a dominantly sandstone protolith.
words.name: Psammite

words.def: Pseudomatrix - weaker material (mainly lithic fragments) that become crushed and become matrix in a rock.
words.name: Pseudomatrix

words.def: Pumice - Light-coloured highly vesicular volcanic rock of very low density.
words.name: Pumice

words.def: Pyroclastic flow - a fast-moving current of hot gas and rock (collectively known as tephra), which normally hugs the ground and travels downhill, or spreads laterally under gravity.
words.name: Pyroclastic flow

words.def: Pyroclastics - volcanic fragments - Volcanic bomb, Breadcrust bomb, Achnelith.
words.name: Pyroclastics

words.def: Pyroxene group - A number of mineral species which although falling into different systems (orthorhombic, monoclinic and triclinic) are closely related in form and structure. They are metasilicates of Calcium, magnesium and iron with manganese, and less often with sodium, potassium, zirconium and fluorine.
words.name: Pyroxene group

words.def: Pyroxenite - A coarse grained holocrystalline igneous rock, consisting mainly of pyroxenes. It may contain biotite, hornblende or olivine as accessories
words.name: Pyroxenite

words.def: Quartzite - Compact, hard, very fine-grained white to creamy white rock, which breaks into sharp angular fragments. Quartzite is always associated with other metamorphic rocks, while cemented sandstone is always associated with other sedimentary rocks.
words.name: Quartzite

words.def: Quaternary - The Quaternary Period is the most recent of the three periods of the Cenozoic Era in the geologic time scale of the ICS. It follows after the Neogene Period, spanning 2.588 ± 0.005 million years ago to the present.
words.name: Quaternary

words.def: Regional metamorphism - Over wide areas resulting from deep burial with consequent rise in temperature and static pressure, usually with the help of folding movements that accompany the formation of mountain ranges
words.name: Regional metamorphism

words.def: Reticulite - Lightest rock known. A basaltic pumice in which the walls of the vesicles have collapsed, leaving a network of fine, interconnecting glass threads.
words.name: Reticulite

words.def: Retrograde metamorphism - the reconstitution of a rock via revolatisation under decreasing temperatures (and usually pressures), allowing the mineral assemblages formed in prograde metamorphism to revert to those more stable at less extreme conditions.
words.name: Retrograde metamorphism

words.def: Reverse fault - Dip-slip faults can be sub-classified into the types "reverse" and "normal". A reverse fault (or thrust fault) occurs when the crust is compressed. The hanging wall moves upward, relative to the footwall.
words.name: Reverse fault

words.def: Rhyolite - Aphantitic, buff to greyish flow-banded rock, often containing spherulites or phenocrysts of quartz and feldspar.
words.name: Rhyolite

words.def: Rift -
words.name: Rift

words.def: Roche moutonnée - a elongated post glacier rock shape with smoothed surface on the uphill side and a "plucked" surface on the downhill side.
words.name: Roche moutonnée

words.def: Rudaceous - Clastic rocks. Coarse grained sedimentary rocks, conglomerates, breccias. Particle size >2mm
words.name: Rudaceous

words.def: Rudite - a general term for sedimentary rocks that are composed of rounded or angular detrital grains, i.e. granules, pebbles, cobbles, and boulders, which are coarser than sand in size.
words.name: Rudite

words.def: Saccharoidal - Having a texture similar to that of granulated sugar.
words.name: Saccharoidal

words.def: Saldanian (orogeny) -
words.name: Saldanian (orogeny)

words.def: Sandstone - Sand (with grains up to 2 mm in diameter) in which the grains are cemented together by secondary silica or calcite. Maybe loosely cemented and soft or well cemented and hard. Buff to brownish; sometimes reddish, due to presence of iron oxides, or greenish, due to presence of glauconite.
words.name: Sandstone

words.def: Sanidine - A form of potash feldspar identical in composition with orthoclase but physically different, formed under different conditions and occurring in different rock types. It is the high temperature form of orthoclase, into which it inverts at 900°C. Occurs in lavas and dyke rocks.
words.name: Sanidine

words.def: Schist - group of medium-grade metamorphic rocks, chiefly notable for the preponderance of lamellar minerals such as micas, chlorite, talc, hornblende, graphite, and others. In the French, schist must be understood as shale.
words.name: Schist

words.def: Sediment trap - a depression where sediments substantially accumulate over time.
words.name: Sediment trap

words.def: Sequence (geology) - a sequence of geological events, processes, or rocks, arranged in chronological order.
words.name: Sequence (geology)

words.def: Sericite - A white potash-mica, like muscovite in chemical composition and general character but occurring as a secondary mineral, often as a decomposition product of orthoclase.
words.name: Sericite

words.def: Shale - a fine-grained, clastic sedimentary rock composed of mud that is a mix of flakes of clay minerals and tiny fragments (silt-sized particles) of other minerals, especially quartz and calcite.
words.name: Shale

words.def: Shear zone - a tabular to sheetlike, planar or curviplanar zone composed of rocks that are more highly strained than rocks adjacent to the zone. See also Fault.
words.name: Shear zone

words.def: Shield - a large area of exposed Precambrian crystalline igneous and high-grade metamorphic rocks that form tectonically stable areas
words.name: Shield

words.def: Silcrete - an indurated soil duricrust formed when surface sand and gravel are cemented by dissolved silica.
words.name: Silcrete

words.def: Silt - granular material of a size somewhere between sand and clay whose mineral origin is quartz and feldspar. Silt may occur as a soil or as suspended sediment (also known as suspended load) in a surface water body. It may also exist as soil deposited at the bottom of a water body.
words.name: Silt

words.def: Slate - very fine-grained sedimentary rock of the clay or silt grade which as a consequence of regional metamorphism has developed a slaty cleavage.
words.name: Slate

words.def: Slaty cleavage - The property of splitting easily along regular, closely spaced planes of fissility, produced by pressure in fine grained rocks, the cleavage planes lying in the directions of maximum elongation of the mass.
words.name: Slaty cleavage

words.def: Slickenside - a smoothly polished surface caused by frictional movement between rocks along the two sides of a fault. This surface is normally striated in the direction of movement.
words.name: Slickenside

words.def: Slump - a form of mass wasting that occurs when a coherent mass of loosely consolidated materials or rock layers moves a short distance down a slope.
words.name: Slump

words.def: Soil liquefaction - process describing the behavior of soils that, when loaded, suddenly suffer a transition from a solid state to a liquefied state, or having the consistency of a heavy liquid.
words.name: Soil liquefaction

words.def: Sorting - Sorting describes the distribution of grain size of sediments, either in unconsolidated deposits or in sedimentary rocks. Very poorly sorted indicates that the sediment sizes are mixed (large variance); whereas well sorted indicates that the sediment sizes are similar (low variance).
words.name: Sorting

words.def: Sphene - Titanite, or sphene, is a calcium titanium nesosilicate mineral.
words.name: Sphene

words.def: Staurolite - a red brown to black, mostly opaque, nesosilicate mineral with a white streak.
words.name: Staurolite

words.def: Strain - A change in the volume or shape of a rock mass in response to stress
words.name: Strain

words.def: Stylolite - an irregular discontinuity or non-structural fracture in limestone and other sedimentary rocks. Stylolites result from compaction and pressure solution during diagenesis.
words.name: Stylolite

words.def: Surficial - Of or pertaining to the surface.
words.name: Surficial

words.def: Syenite - A coarse grained igneous rock of intermediate composition, composed essentially of alkali-feldspar to the extent of at least two thirds of the total, with a variable content of mafic materials, of which common hornblende is characteristic.
words.name: Syenite

words.def: Syncline - Geological fold with strata dipping inwards towards fold axis
words.name: Syncline

words.def: Syntaxis -
words.name: Syntaxis

words.def: Table Mountain Group - a group of rock formations within the Cape Supergroup sequence of rocks.
words.name: Table Mountain Group

words.def: Talus - Scree is a collection of broken rock fragments at the base of crags, mountain cliffs, volcanoes or valley shoulders that has accumulated through periodic rockfall from adjacent cliff faces. Landforms associated with these materials are often called talus deposits.
words.name: Talus

words.def: Tectonics - large-scale processes affecting the structure of the earth's crust.
words.name: Tectonics

words.def: Tephra - Tephra is fragmental material produced by a volcanic eruption regardless of composition, fragment size or emplacement mechanism. Once clasts have fallen to the ground they remain as tephra unless hot enough to fuse together into pyroclastic rock or tuff.
words.name: Tephra

words.def: Tethys Ocean - (Greek: Τηθύς) - ocean that existed between the continents of Gondwana and Laurasia during the Mesozoic era before the opening of the Indian Ocean.
words.name: Tethys Ocean

words.def: Till - Till or glacial till is unsorted glacial sediment. Glacial drift is a general term for the coarsely graded and extremely heterogeneous sediments of glacial origin. Glacial till is that part of glacial drift which was deposited directly by the glacier.
words.name: Till

words.def: Tillite - Till which has been indurated or lithified by subsequent burial into solid rock, is known as the sedimentary rock tillite
words.name: Tillite

words.def: Topography - the arrangement of the natural and artificial physical features of an area.
words.name: Topography

words.def: Tor - a large, free-standing residual mass (rock outcrop) that rises abruptly from the surrounding smooth and gentle slopes of a rounded hill summit or ridge crest.
words.name: Tor

words.def: Trachyte - A fine grained igneous rock type of intermediate composition, in most cases with little or no quartz, consisting largely of alkali-feldspars (sanidene or oligooclase) together with a small amount of coloured silicates such as diopside, horneblende, or mica.
words.name: Trachyte

words.def: Travertine - a terrestrial sedimentary rock, formed by the precipitation of carbonate minerals from solution in ground and surface waters, and/or geothermally heated hot-springs.
words.name: Travertine

words.def: Triclinic - In the triclinic system, the crystal is described by vectors of unequal length, and none of the three vectors are orthogonal to another.
words.name: Triclinic

words.def: Tuff - A rock formed of compacted volcanic fragments, some of which can be distinguished by the naked eye. If the fragments are larger than the rock grades into an agglomerate.
words.name: Tuff

words.def: Tundra - a vast, flat, treeless Arctic region of Europe, Asia, and North America in which the subsoil is permanently frozen.
words.name: Tundra

words.def: Turbidite - the deposit of a turbidity current.
words.name: Turbidite

words.def: Turbidity current - a current of rapidly moving, sediment-laden water moving down a slope through water, or another fluid. The current moves because it has a higher density than the fluid through which it flows.
words.name: Turbidity current

words.def: Ultramafic - Almost feldspar free. Ultrabasic. [dunite, peridotite, pyroxenite]
words.name: Ultramafic

words.def: Urchin - or sea urchin - small, spiny, globular animal belonging to the class of Echinoidea. Urchins inhabit all oceans. Their shell, or "test", is round and spiny, typically from 3 to 10 centimetres (1.2 to 3.9 in) across.
words.name: Urchin

words.def: Urgonian - shallow-water carbonate facies deposited along the northern margins of the Tethys Ocean during the Barremian and Aptian
words.name: Urgonian

words.def: Vacuoles - Bubble inclusions within mineral grains (typically monocrystalline quartz), filled with liquid, liquid and gas, or gas alone. They are randomly distributed in contrast to the oriented bubble trains of 'Boehm Lamellae'
words.name: Vacuoles

words.def: Variscan orogeny - or Hercynian orogeny - is a geologic mountain-building event caused by Late Paleozoic continental collision between Euramerica (Laurussia) and Gondwana to form the supercontinent of Pangaea.
words.name: Variscan orogeny

words.def: Varve - an annual layer of sediment or sedimentary rock.
words.name: Varve

words.def: Vein (geology) - Mineral filling of a fracture or other crack within a rock in a sheet-like or tabular shape.
words.name: Vein (geology)

words.def: Vermiculite - a hydrous, silicate mineral that is classified as a phyllosilicate and that expands greatly when heated. Exfoliation occurs when the mineral is heated sufficiently.
words.name: Vermiculite

words.def: Vergence (geology) - direction of overturning of asymmetric folds - matches direction of thrusting.
words.name: Vergence (geology)

words.def: Vesiculated -
words.name: Vesiculated

words.def: Vitrinite - a group of macerals, that are the most common component of coal
words.name: Vitrinite

words.def: Vitrophyre - see Pitchstone
words.name: Vitrophyre

words.def: Volcanic - Rocks that have crystallised from magma poured out at the surface or introduced at shallow depth. They have cooled relatively rapidly, grain size of crystals is small, some part of the melt may solidify as glass, volatiles are lost and anhydrous minerals of high temperature of crystallisation are present.
words.name: Volcanic

words.def: Volcanic bomb - Rounded or spindle-shaped rock of mainly basaltic composition ejected during eruptions.
words.name: Volcanic bomb

words.def: Vug - Small cavity in a rock filled or lined with crystals/minerals that are different from the host rock.
words.name: Vug

words.def: Wiggle trace - a graph that plots wave amplitudes (recorded by seismic reflection and borehole logging) as a function of time, with the positive peaks shaded in a single dark color.
words.name: Wiggle trace

words.def: Wolframite - (Fe,Mn)WO4 - an iron manganese tungstate mineral.
words.name: Wolframite

words.def: Xenolith - a rock fragment which becomes enveloped in a larger rock during the latter's development and hardening. In geology, the term xenolith is almost exclusively used to describe inclusions in igneous rock during magma emplacement and eruption.
words.name: Xenolith

words.def: Xenotime - a rare earth phosphate mineral, whose major component is yttrium orthophosphate (YPO4).
words.name: Xenotime

words.def: XRD - X-ray diffraction - a method of determining the arrangement of atoms within a crystal, in which a beam of X-rays strikes a crystal and diffracts into many specific directions.
words.name: XRD

words.def: XRF - X-ray fluorescence - the emission of characteristic "secondary" (or fluorescent) X-rays from a material that has been excited by bombarding with high-energy X-rays or gamma rays. The phenomenon is widely used for elemental analysis and chemical analysis of minerals.
words.name: XRF

words.def: Xyloid coal - also known as lignite, often referred to as brown coal, is a soft brown fuel with characteristics that put it somewhere between coal and peat.
words.name: Xyloid coal

words.def: Yellow cake - or Yellowcake (also called urania) - a kind of uranium concentrate powder obtained from leach solutions, in an intermediate step in the processing of uranium ores.
words.name: Yellow cake

words.def: Young's modulus - in solid mechanics, Young's modulus, also known as the tensile modulus, is a measure of the stiffness of an isotropic elastic material. It is defined as the ratio of the uniaxial stress over the uniaxial strain in the range of stress in which Hooke's Law holds.
words.name: Young's modulus

words.def: Ypresian - In the geologic timescale the Ypresian is the oldest age or lowest stratigraphic stage of the Eocene. It spans the time between ~56 Ma and ~49 Ma (million years ago).
words.name: Ypresian

words.def: Zeolite - microporous, aluminosilicate minerals commonly used as adsorbent.
words.name: Zeolite

words.def: Zircon - a zirconium silicate mineral belonging to the group of nesosilicates. Its corresponding chemical formula is ZrSiO4.
words.name: Zircon
